question: Girls, this is it. In a few hours, I'll be the future Mrs. Warner Huntington III.
answer: You're beautiful.

question: So are you!
answer: You ready?

answer: I mean, we're having a lot of fun now -- but things are gonna be different when I ' m at Harvard Law school is a completely different world. I need to be serious.

answer: My family expects a lot from me. And I expect a lot from me. I .plan on running for office some day.

question: And I fully support that. I completely agree.
answer: T hat 's why I think it's time for us to-- Elle takes a deep breath, filled with anticipation. I think we should break up. Elle's champagne glass drops from her hand and CRASHES onto the patio.

answer: I ' m sorry, Elle, I just --

answer: Proposing?! Elle, If I ' m going to be a politician, I need to marry a Jackie, not a -- Marilyn.

answer: I do love you, Elle. I just can't marry you. You have no idea the pressure I ' m under. My family has five generations of senators. My brother is in the top three at Yale Law. He  just got engaged to a Vanderbilt, for crissakes. Elle stares at him aghast, tears streaming down her face, then pushes her chair away from the table and walks out. It's not like I have a choice, sweetheart C'mon. Let me take you home.

question: No.
answer: Elle -- it's twenty miles back to campus. Elle stops, thinks a minute, then gets in, still crying. Catching her poofy little purse in the door. She re-opens i t, yanking the purse back in. Warner pulls out. Elle, believe me, I never expected to be doing this, but I think it's the right thing to do.

answer: East coast people are different.

question: Just because I ' m not a Vanderbilt, all of a sudden I ' m white trash? I grew up in Bel Air, Warner! Across the street from Aaron Spelling! I think most people would agree that's way better than a Vanderb ilt --
answer: I told you, Elle. I need someone -- serious.

question: I ' m seriously in love with you -- Isn't that enough? He looks away.
answer: I ' m sorry. She gets out of the car and drags herself up the stairs to her sorority house. When she's at the top, she turns back to look at him. His perfect cheekbones highlighted by the streetlamp. He meets her eyes, pained, but determined. Then pulls away, leaving her there.

answer: Here. You're gonna need this.

question: Your scrunchie?
answer: My lucky scrunchie. It helped me pass Spanish. Serena rolls her eyes and looks at Margot disapprovingly. Yeah, luckily.

question: My name is Elle Woods and for my admissions essay, I ' d like to tell all of you at Harvard why I ' m going to make an amazing lawyer. As president of my sorority, I ' m skilled at commanding the attention of a room and discussing important issues. Elle bangs a gavel, as she sits in front of her sisters. ~ It has come to my attention that the maintenance staff is switching our toilet paper from Charmin to generic. All those opposed to chafing, pleas.e say "aye". The sisters "AYE" in unison. Underdog barks his approval. I ' m able to recall hundreds of important details at the drop of a hat. question: Elle?!
answer: Warner?! Oh my God, I completely forgot you were going here!

question: You go where?
answer: Harvard. Law school.

question: A legal education means you will learn to speak in a new language. You will be taught to achieve insight into the world around you, and to sharply question what you know. Everyone soaks this up. Including Elle. The seat you've picked is yours for the next nine months of your life. Enjoy it. And those of you in the front row, beware. . .. El le , in the front row, between two UNSHOWERED BRANIACS,  looks around, panicked. One of the braniacs passes her the seating chart and she has no choice but to sign her name. In the back, Arrogant Aaron nudges his friend and smiles. "The law is reason free from passion." Does anyone know who spoke those immortal words? Dorky David raises his hand. Yes?
answer: Aristotle.

question: Are you sure?
answer: Yes?

question: ~ Would you be willing to stake your life on it?

question: H o w about -- -- his life?

answer: Absolutely. Elle can't believe that this girl would betray her. Having no choice,, she gathers her purse and goes, completely humiliated. Professor Stromwell returns to the matter at hand.

answer: Do they just -- put you on the spot like that? Like, all the time?

answer: And if you don't know the answer, they just kick you out? He smiles.

question: You have Stromwell.

question: Don't worry. It gets better. Who else do you have? Elle looks at her schedule.

answer: Wow. I ' m glad I met you.

question: Bad day?

I wish I ' d never even come to Harvard.

answer: I believe you've just won your case. You did well today.

answer: . I ' m Elle Woods. Ms. Bonaf ante's  . attorney. Under state law, you and Ms. Bonaf ante had a common law marriage which entitles her to the benefits of property law and an equitable division of assets.

question: But I can't tell you what it is. Yes.

answer: Someone reason with her while I take this.

question: But maybe it's not what you think.

question: Okay, how would it work? -- I can't.

answer: Chuck. The audience lets out a gasp. Elle looks up, shocked, then delighted. I ' m sorry, I misunderstood. Chuck is just a friend.

question: What're you so happy about? You're on trial for murder.

The DA rolls her eyes, as do the lawyers present. Okay -- Ms. Windham, when you uh arrived back at the house? Was your father there?

question: Where you got in the shower.

answer: Because they got wet.

question: That's right. Because isn't the first cardinal rule of perm maintenance that you are forbidden to wet your hair for at least twenty-four hours after getting a perm at the risk of de-activating the ammonium thiglycolate?
answer: Yes -- Elle continues.

question: And wouldn't someone who's had -- thirty perms ? -- throughout her lifetime, be well aware of this rule? And if you, in fact, were not washing your hair, as I suspect you were not, since your curls are still intact, wouldn't you have heard the gunshot? And if you in fact, heard the gunshot, then Brooke Windham wouldn't have had time to hide the gun before you got downstairs. Which would mean that you would've had to have found Mrs. Windham with a gun in her hand to make your story sound plausible. Isn't that right?
answer: She's younger than I am. Did she tell you that? How would you feel if your father married someone younger than you?

question: You, however, had time to hide the gun, didn't you, Chutney? After you shot your father?
answer: I didn't mean to shoot him --  I meant to shoot you!

question: Don't worry. She's harmless. I'll see you guys soon! Thanks for coming! She air-kisses them as Margot leads a still shell-shocked Serena away as Emmett walks up to Elle.
answer: You were amazing today. She turns and finds Warner.

question: Thank you. He moves closer.
answer: It made me realize something. I ' m an idiot. I want to be with you, Elle. Forever. He pulls her close, hand around her waist, kissing her. She looks up at him, a trace of the old love in her eyes. For a moment, she melts.

question: In court. On opposing sides.
answer: Are you serious?

question: Huh. Imagine that. Looks like I am. She walks down the steps. Warner watches her go, then turns to see Sarah, who's witnessed the entire episode. She glares at him, then walks past.
answer: El le , wait up -- Elle turns. I ' m a bitch.

question: Yes, you are.
answer: And Donovan's a-scumbag for coming on to you. So -- can we drink that champagne when I get back from the pawnshop? She pulls off her engagement ring.
